answer_html: and so this really is the inverse of \(f\).
answer_latex: and so this really is the inverse of $f$.
hints_html:
Why doesn’t the function

\[\begin{aligned} f : \{0,1\} &\to \{3\}\\ 0 &\mapsto 3\\ 1 &\mapsto 3\end{aligned}\]

have an inverse?

What about the function

\[\begin{aligned} g: \{0\} &\to \{1,2\}\\ 0 &\mapsto 2\end{aligned}\]
hints_latex:
Why doesn't the function

\begin{align*}
f : \{0,1\} &\to \{3\}\\
0 &\mapsto 3\\
1 &\mapsto 3
\end{align*} have an inverse?

What about the function

\begin{align*}
g: \{0\} &\to \{1,2\}\\
0 &\mapsto 2
\end{align*}
hints_raw:
Why doesn't the function
:<math>\begin{align}
f : \{0,1\} &\to \{3\}\\
0 &\mapsto 3\\
1 &\mapsto 3
\end{align}</math>
have an inverse?

What about the function
:<math>\begin{align}
g: \{0\} &\to \{1,2\}\\
0 &\mapsto 2
\end{align}</math>
question: 1 (e)
sols_html:
A function \(f\) has an inverse if and only if it is bijective. That is, it has an inverse if and only if it is

  1. Injective (or one-to-one)

  2. Surjective (or onto).

In such a case, for every y \(\in\) B, there is a unique x \(\in\) A such that \(f(x)\) = y. Using this fact, we define \(f\)-1 by the rule

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f^{-1}(y) = x\end{aligned}\]

where x is the unique element of the set A such that \(f(x)\) = y. From the injectivity and surjectivity, this is well defined. Moreover,

\[\begin{aligned} f\big(f^{-1}(y)\big) = f(x) = y\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} f^{-1}\big(f(x)\big) = f^{-1}(y) = x\end{aligned}\]

and so this really is the inverse of \(f\).
sols_latex:
A function $f$ has an inverse if and only if it is \emph{bijective}. That
is, it has an inverse if and only if it is

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  Injective (or one-to-one)
\item
  Surjective (or onto).
\end{enumerate}

In such a case, for every \emph{y} $\in$ \emph{B}, there is a unique
\emph{x} $\in$ \emph{A} such that $f(x)$ = \emph{y}. Using this fact,
we define $f$\textsuperscript{-1} by the rule

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f^{-1}(y) = x
\end{align*}

where \emph{x} is the unique element of the set \emph{A} such that
$f(x)$ = \emph{y}. From the injectivity and surjectivity, this is
well defined. Moreover,

\begin{align*}
f\big(f^{-1}(y)\big) = f(x) = y
\end{align*}

and

\begin{align*}
f^{-1}\big(f(x)\big) = f^{-1}(y) = x
\end{align*}

and so this really is the inverse of $f$.
sols_raw:
A function &fnof; has an inverse if and only if it is ''bijective''. That is, it has an inverse if and only if it is

# Injective (or one-to-one)
# Surjective (or onto).

In such a case, for every ''y'' &isin; ''B'', there is a unique ''x'' &isin; ''A'' such that &fnof;(''x'') = ''y''.  Using this fact, we define &fnof;<sup>-1</sup> by the rule

:<math>\displaystyle
f^{-1}(y) = x
</math>

where ''x'' is the unique element of the set ''A'' such that &fnof;(''x'') = ''y''. From the injectivity and surjectivity, this is well defined. Moreover,

:<math>
f\big(f^{-1}(y)\big) = f(x) = y
</math>

and

:<math>
f^{-1}\big(f(x)\big) = f^{-1}(y) = x
</math>

and so this really is the inverse of &fnof;.
statement_html: Let A, B be non-empty sets, and let \(f\): A \(\rightarrow\) B be a function. When does \(f\) have an inverse function \(f\)-1? Define \(f\)-1.
statement_raw: Let ''A'', ''B'' be non-empty sets, and let &fnof;: ''A'' &rarr; ''B'' be a function. When does &fnof; have an inverse function &fnof;<sup>-1</sup>? Define &fnof;<sup>-1</sup>.
